{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Other people5|Joe Riley (disambiguation){{!}}Joe Riley}} {{Infobox writer | name = Jo Riley | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Josephine Riley | birth_date = (20th century)<!--{{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = writer, translator, [[theatre actor]], [[schoolteacher]] | nationality = <!--old stub alleged English but no source/proof--> | citizenship = British | education = PhD | alma_mater = [[University of Cambridge]] | period = <!--dates from first to last publication--> | subject = [[Chinese theatre]], [[theatre arts]] | notableworks = ''Chinese Theatre and the Actor in Performance'' (1997) | spouse = <!--only if blue link--> | partner = <!--only if blue link--> | children = <!--only if blue link--> | relatives = <!--only if blue link--> | awards = | signature = | website = }} [[File:HuangmeiOpera.jpg|thumb|An example of [[Huangmei opera]] performance.]] '''Josephine Riley''' is a British writer, translator, theatre actor, and schoolteacher. Dr. Riley has written and translated several books about [[theatre arts]], especially [[Chinese theatre]]. She currently teaches film and drama at [[Munich International School]] in Germany.
<!--[[WP:NOTABILITY]] paragraph-->Riley reads, writes, and speaks [[Mandarin Chinese]], and is better known for having in the early 1980s widely traveled in China and learned to act in the [[Chinese theatre]]<ref name=Mackerras1999/> as one of the first foreign students at the [[Central Academy of Drama in Beijing]],<ref name=ISTA2008/> eventually writing ''Chinese Theatre and the Actor in Performance'' (1997, [[Cambridge University Press]]), a reference book that "gives an 'inside' view of Chinese theatre and the actor in performance for the first time [...] from her personal observations of, and dialogue with, Chinese actors and her first-hand experiences of the theatre world of China in general, none of which was possible before 1980."<ref name=pubdesc>[http://catdir.loc.gov/catdir/description/cam028/96031554.html Publisher description for the book], archived at the [[Library of Congress]], catdir.loc.gov.</ref> She also made the first English translation of ''[[The Other Shore (play)|The Other Shore]]'' by [[Nobel Laureate in Literature]] playwright [[Gao Xingjian]].
==Biography==
===Life=== [[File:Chinese theater.jpg|thumb|An example of Chinese theater.]] Jo Riley graduated from the [[University of Cambridge]].<ref name=ISTA2008>ISTA 2008.</ref> After working for a number of small touring companies, she went to Asia to explore a different kind of theatre. In the early 1980s, after learning [[Mandarin Chinese]], she was one of the first foreign students at the [[Central Academy of Drama in Beijing]],<ref name=ISTA2008/> where she learned to act in the [[Chinese theatre]] (''example pictured at right'').<ref name=Mackerras1999/>
She has since then helped teach and direct traditional Chinese theatre in Salzburg, Mainz, and Bayreuth.<ref name=ISTA2008/> She's also been at intercultural workshops with Cardiff Laboratory Theatre and Pan Projects at Goldsmiths College, London.<ref name=ISTA2008/> In addition, she has written articles and books on Chinese theatre, especially ''Chinese Theatre and the Actor in Performance'' (1997, see Works section), and has edited or translated several plays or books on European and [[intercultural theatre]].
She currently teaches drama at [[Munich International School]]<ref name=ISTA2008/> in Germany.
===Works=== [[File:Beijing-Opera2.jpg|thumb|An example of male performer of ''jingju'', the [[Beijing opera]].]] In 1997, [[Cambridge University Press]] published Riley's ''Chinese Theatre and the Actor in Performance'', a book often cited on the topic of [[Chinese theatre]]. It covers not only ''jingju'' ([[Beijing opera]] or Peking opera, ''example pictured at right'') but also Chinese puppet theatre and [[shadow play]], as well as Chinese exorcism and ancient animation rites at the tomb, to explore how the Chinese create presence on a stage.<ref name=pubdesc/> In a 1999 review for the ''[[Asian Theatre Journal]]'', China specialist Prof. [[Colin Mackerras]] (author of ''The Cambridge Handbook of Contemporary China'', brother of [[Malcolm Mackerras]]) noted how the book "looks at the skills of the Chinese actor from the insider's point of view – not that of the Westerner or the student of China."<ref name=Mackerras1999>Mackerras 1999.</ref> Indeed:
{{quote|Jo Riley is one of the few people in the West qualified to undertake such a study because she not only knows Chinese but has learned to act in the Chinese theatre. She has traveled widely in China and examined the various styles of regional theatre that are so abundant and important in China. Although nobody can really divorce himself from his own culture, nor is it sensible to try, Jo Riley does speak as an insider of the Chinese theatre in a way few non-Chinese can match.<ref name=Mackerras1999/>}}
Riley also made, under the title ''The Other Side'' (1997), the first English translation of the controversial play ''[[The Other Shore (play)|The Other Shore]]'' (1986) by [[Nobel Laureate in Literature]] playwright [[Gao Xingjian]].
==Bibliography==
===As editor=== Edited or co-edited publications include: * 1990: ''The Dramatic Touch of Difference: Theatre, Own and Foreign'', by various *: Collected essays edited by [[Erika Fischer-Lichte]]<sup><!--until blue link-->([[:de:Erika Fischer-Lichte|in German]])</sup>, Jo Riley, & Michael Gissenwehrer, Forum Modernes Theater, <!--"Schriftenreihe"=Series, "Band"=Volume-->vol. 2, Tübingen: <!--no umlaut on Gun-->Gunter Narr Verlag, 1990, {{ISBN|3-8233-4023-9}}, {{LCCN|90190502}}, {{OCLC|22509815}}, [[GBOOK]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=BoB6jbZqbhgC BoB6jbZqbhgC]; 287 p., illustrations, paperback – Co-credit was to "Josephine Riley". * 1997: ''The Show and the Gaze of Theatre: A European Perspective'', by [[Erika Fischer-Lichte]]<sup><!--until blue link-->([[:de:Erika Fischer-Lichte|in German]])</sup> *: Collected essays (1986–1995) edited (and some translated from the German into English) by Jo Riley, Studies in Theatre History and Culture, Iowa City: [[University of Iowa Press]], November 1997, {{ISBN|0-87745-608-9}}<!--pbk out before hbk-->, {{LCCN|97024047}}, {{OCLC|37392802}}, [[GBOOK]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=HF3wu1vVm2gC HF3wu1vVm2gC]; 426 (x, 412) p., illustrations, paperback. (Hardback: February 1998, {{ISBN|0-87745-607-0}}<!--same OCLC as pbk-->)
===As author=== Publications include: * 1997: ''Chinese Theatre and the Actor in Performance'' *: Cambridge studies in modern theatre, Cambridge, UK: [[Cambridge University Press]], June 1997, {{ISBN|0-521-57090-5}}, {{LCCN|96031554}}, {{OCLC|35085033}}, [[GBOOK]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=OIAiYaIfFagC OIAiYaIfFagC]; 360 (xii, 348) p., illustrations, hardback. (Paperback: December 2006, {{ISBN|0-521-03523-6}}, {{OCLC|150387657}}.)
===As translator=== Translations include: * 1997: ''[[The Other Side: A Contemporary Drama Without Acts]]'', by [[Gao Xingjian]] *: Translated from the Chinese ''Bi An'' (1986; {{zh|c=彼岸|p=bǐ'àn<!--bi3'an4-->}}) into English by Jo Riley, in Martha P. Y. Cheung & Jane C. C. Lai (eds.), ''An Oxford Anthology of Contemporary Chinese Drama'', p. 149–184<!--Prose: 152-183-->, Hong Kong & New York: [[Oxford University Press]], September 1997, {{ISBN|0-19-586880-3}}, {{LCCN|97005298}}, {{OCLC|36283949}}, [[GBOOK]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=XUFkAAAAMAAJ XUFkAAAAMAAJ]; 900 (xxvi, 873) p., hardback – Part of an anthology of 15 plays. This play was later retranslated by someone else as ''[[The Other Shore (play)|The Other Shore]]'' for a different collection of plays. * 2001: ''History of European Drama and Theatre'', by [[Erika Fischer-Lichte]]<sup><!--until blue link-->([[:de:Erika Fischer-Lichte|in German]])</sup> *: Translated from the German ''Geschichte des Dramas'' (1990) into English by Jo Riley, London, UK & New York: [[Routledge]], December 2001, {{ISBN|0-415-18059-7}}, {{LCCN|2001034969}}, {{OCLC|48110496}}, [[GBOOK]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=5JWfX8mjX8AC 5JWfX8mjX8AC]; 432 (x, 396<!--sic-->) p., hardback. (Paperback: May 2004, {{ISBN|0-415-18060-0}}, {{OCLC|56222522}}.)

[http://www.ista.co.uk/files/London%201%20TAPS%20Teacher%20Information%20Pack.doc "Teacher Information Pack for the London 1 TAPS" (Theatre Arts Programmes Symposium)] ([[Word document]]), [[International Schools Theatre Association]] (ISTA), 2008 – Contains a self-bio. * <!--red link for notable-->[[Colin Mackerras|Mackerras, Colin]] (1999). "Chinese Theatre and the Actor in Performance. By Jo Riley" (book review), ''[[Asian Theatre Journal]]'', [[University of Hawaii Press]], {{ISSN|0742-5457}}, vol. 16, no. 1 (Spring 1999), {{JSTOR|stable=1124450}}<!--old format: {{JSTOR stable URL|0742-5457(199921)16%3A1%3C127%3ACTATAI%3E2.0.CO%3B2-B}}-->, p. 127–129

{{Infobox Journal | title = Journal of Business Ethics Education | cover = | editor = John Hooker | discipline = [[Business ethics]], [[Education]], [[Philosophy]] | abbreviation = J. Bus. Ethics Educ. | publisher = NeilsonJournals Publishing | country = | frequency = Annual | history = 2004-present | website = http://www.neilsonjournals.com/JBEE/ | link2 = http://secure.pdcnet.org/jbee/toc | link2-name = Tables of content, 2004-present | link3 = | link3-name = | RSS = | atom = | OCLC = 60386769 | JSTOR = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 1649-5195 | eISSN = 2041-6962 }} The '''''Journal of Business Ethics Education''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] that examines the particular challenges facing business ethics educators. It publishes articles, case studies, and reviews intended to help instructors do a better job in the classroom. Established in 2004, the journal is edited by John Hooker at Carnegie Mellon University, and published by NeilsonJournals Publishing in print and electronic formats. The journal is also available online from the [[Philosophy Documentation Center]].

{{Primary sources|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox Organization |name = National Association of Independent Schools |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = NAIS |motto = |formation = |extinction = |type = [[Non-governmental organization]] |status = |purpose = [[K-12 education]] |headquarters = |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = ''Independent School'' |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.nais.org nais.org] |remarks = }} {{Education in the U.S.}} The '''National Association of Independent Schools''' ('''NAIS''') is a [[United States|U.S.]]-based membership organization for private, nonprofit, K-12 schools. Founded in 1963, NAIS represents [[independent school]]s and associations in the United States, including [[day school|day]], [[boarding school|boarding]], and day/boarding schools; elementary and secondary schools; boys', girls', and coeducational schools. NAIS has affiliate members internationally as well.
NAIS's mission is to be the national voice of independent schools and the center for [[collective action]] on their behalf.
==Membership== As of the 2010-11 school year, NAIS represented approximately 1,400 member independent schools and associations in the US, serving more than 562,000 students and 121,000 teachers, administrators, and other staff.
Membership in NAIS is open to independent pre-college schools that are operated by [[nonprofit]] organizations. To become a full member of NAIS, a school must have operated for at least five years and must be [[educational accreditation|accredited]] by an accrediting organization approved by NAIS.<ref>[http://www.nais.org/about/index.cfm?ItemNumber=145935&sn.ItemNumber=1482&tn.ItemNumber=62506 Membership], NAIS website, accessed October 6, 2010</ref>
== NAIS Commission on Accreditation ==
===Background===
In response to requests from several state, regional, and national accrediting organizations, the NAIS Commission on Accreditation was established by the NAIS Board of Trustees in 2001 and convened for the first time in 2002. The 19 member Commission’s work is intended to assure the quality of independent school accrediting programs.
A primary responsibility of the Commission is to developing a public understanding of, and credibility for, state and regional accrediting programs. In addition, the Commission,
* develops criteria for effective independent school accreditation practices, exemplary standards, and models of successful accreditation policies and procedures. * engages in research to inform accreditation practice.
The Commission meets on a regular basis and is guided by established operating protocols. It is composed of members from state and regional accrediting associations that are members of NAIS was well as at-large members, and NAIS Board members.
===Accountability===
The member associations of the Commission are accountable to one another through a process patterned on the independent school accreditation model. Over the course of a 10-year cycle, associations prepare a self-study demonstrating compliance with the Criteria for Effective Independent School Accreditation Practices. The criteria provide common ground for member associations by delineating best practices, policies, and procedures. In addition, associations use the Model Core Standards — a set of “ideal” standards — in assessing their own standards. As part of the process of “accrediting the accreditors”, each member association hosts a visit from other Commissioners, receives written recommendations from the Commission, and engages in follow-up activities designed to improve the state or regional accreditation process. As with school accreditation, this will serve two purposes: institutional improvement and quality assurance.
===Criteria for Effective Independent School Accreditation Practices===
Each member associations must be determined to be in compliance with the following:
# The accrediting association holds schools accountable to a comprehensive set of standards related to the educational program and issues of institutional health. # The accrediting association, recognizing that accreditation is a peer review process, institutes policies and procedures that ensure fairness and impartiality and that are free of conflicts of interest, both in appearance and in fact. # The accreditation process consists of a continuing cycle: self-study by the school, visit and report by a team of trained peers, action by the association, and follow-up by the school and the association. # The accrediting association monitors the school’s compliance with standards and its progress in addressing the recommendations of the self-study and of the visiting team report. The accrediting association also regularly solicits reports from schools on substantive institutional change and reviews the school’s accreditation status in the light of those changes. # The decision-making and appeal processes regarding accreditation status in the accreditation cycle are clear and understandable. Policies and procedures are available for public review. # The accrediting association offers formal and comprehensive preparation and training for all participants in the accreditation process, including team chairs and members, heads of school, self-study coordinators, and accrediting association boards and commissions. # The accrediting association engages in regular evaluation and review of its standards and accreditation process and solicits reports from schools and visiting teams on their experience with the process. # The accrediting association designates a decision-making body charged with overseeing the evaluation and accreditation process and making final decisions regarding accreditation. # The accreditation process examines the whole school, including all divisions and those programs that are included in the accreditation. # The accrediting association has a procedure, available to the public and clearly explained, to handle complaints that accredited schools are not meeting standards. # The accreditation process rests on comprehensive standards which schools must meet. The standards address all areas of school life, including the following: mission, governance, finance, program, community of the school, administration, development, admissions, personnel, health and safety, facilities, student services, school culture, and residential life (where applicable). # The standards require schools to conduct a thoughtful assessment of individual student progress consistent with the school’s mission. # The standards require a school to provide evidence of a thoughtful process, respectful of its mission, for informed decision-making that draws on data (both internal and external) about student learning. # The standards require a school to demonstrate that its educational programs, instructional practices, and institutional culture are informed by relevant research regarding how students learn and the knowledge and capacities they will need to lead purposeful and constructive lives. # The self-study process is deliberative, and the self-study report reflects the considered judgment of the school’s professional community. # A broad cross-section of the community (including all faculty and staff, as well as members of the governing body and others in the community, as appropriate) participate in preparing the self-study. # The self-study includes reflection and self-analysis as well as description, identifies strengths and weaknesses, and assesses both the school’s compliance with standards and the congruence between its program and mission, and balances documentation of accountability to the accrediting association standards with a focus on school improvement. The school will provide all required documents in a timely fashion. # The accrediting association appoints a visiting team chair who shall be responsible to follow the accrediting association’s guidelines, to ensure the visiting team’s effectiveness, and to protect the integrity of the process. # The accrediting association appoints a visiting team to conduct a site visit while school is in session. # The accrediting association is mindful of the circumstances of the school and the full range of the standards in determining the size and selecting the members of a visiting team. # The visiting team receives advance materials in a timely fashion and arrives at the school fully prepared. # The visiting team observes the program and interviews school staff, trustees, students, parents, and others as appropriate. It validates the self-study, evaluates the school’s compliance with standards, and writes a report with commendations and recommendations which is sent to the accrediting association and to the school in a timely fashion. The report is confidential, except as authorized by the school. Any release of parts or all of the report to the public must follow the accrediting association guidelines. # The length of the visit is sufficient to accomplish the above. # The members of the visiting team hold confidential the information they receive and their discussions during the accreditation process. # The accrediting association, or a representative committee, receives and reviews the self-study, and visiting team report, determines the accreditation status of the school, prescribes appropriate actions, and sets up a schedule for future reports and visits. The school is given an opportunity to respond to the report of the visiting committee in advance of the accrediting association taking action on its accreditation. # The accrediting association notifies the board chair, as well as the head of school, concerning decisions related to a school’s accreditation.
=== Membership on the NAIS Commission on Accreditation ===
The following are state, regional, and international accrediting organizations that are members of the NAIS Commission on Accreditation:

'''Regional, National and International Accrediting Associations''' * * [http://www.cais.ca Canadian Accredited Independent Schools (CAIS/CAN)] * [http://www.cois.org Council of International Schools (CIS)] * [http://www.aisne.org Association of Independent Schools in New England (AISNE)] * [http://www.isacs.org Independent Schools Association of the Central States (ISACS)] * [http://www.isasw.org Independent Schools Association of the Southwest (ISAS)] * [http://www.neasc.org New England Association of Schools and Colleges (NEASC)] * [http://www.nwais.org Northwest Association of Independent Schools (NWAIS)] * [http://www.sais.org Southern Association of Independent Schools (SAIS)] * [http://www.swaes.org Southwest Association of Episcopal Schools (SAES)]

revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name = North Star: Self-Directed Learning for Teens | image = Image:North_Star_staff_and_teens.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Gathering of teens and staff (2010) | motto = '''"Learning is natural. School is optional."''' | address = 45 Amherst Road | city = [[Sunderland, Massachusetts|Sunderland]] | state = [[Massachusetts]] | zipcode = 01375 | country = United States of America | coordinates = {{Coord|42|27|55.5|N|72|34|34.1|W|format=dms|type:edu_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | type = Self-directed learning center | established = {{Start date|1996}} | founders = Kenneth Danford, Joshua Hornick | director = Kenneth Danford | staff = 8 (2016) | age_range = 11 to 19 years | enrollment = 60+ | affiliation = Nonsectarian | alumni = 500+ | information = fee-based, nonprofit | website = {{URL|northstarteens.org}} }}
'''North Star: Self Directed Learning for Teens''' is a [[Autodidacticism|self-directed]] learning center in [[Sunderland, Massachusetts]], founded in 1996. North Star's mission is to help [[teenagers]] find ways to learn and excel outside of traditional [[Middle school#United States|middle school]] and [[high school]]. It offers a noncoercive learning environment without required classes, grades, or tests.<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://northstarteens.org/about/guiding-principles/ |title = North Star {{!}} Guiding Principles |website = northstarteens.org |access-date = 2016-02-26 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160306210653/http://northstarteens.org/about/guiding-principles/ |archivedate = 2016-03-06 |df = }}</ref> Members range in age from 11 to 19 years old. Both previously-schooled teens and long-time [[Homeschooling|homeschoolers]] attend the center. As of 2015, North Star has over 60 members<ref>{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Richie|title=North Star celebrates 20 years of self-directed learning for teens at new home in Sunderland|url=http://www.gazettenet.com/home/19094435-95/north-star-celebrates-20-years-of-self-directed-learning-for-teens-at-new-home-in|website=Gazettenet.com|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref> and over 500 alumni from all over the [[Pioneer Valley]] and beyond.
North Star was founded by two Massachusetts middle school teachers who were frustrated with a system that forced students to attend their classes.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|last1=Turner|first1=Maureen|title=The Unschool|url=http://www.valleyadvocate.com/2012/06/14/the-unschool/|website=Valley Advocate|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref> In contrast, North Star supports teenagers to self-direct their own education, offering a program of optional classes, tutoring, trips and community events, taught and organized by North Star's professional staff and an extensive network of volunteers. Each North Star member is paired with an advisor who supports and encourages the teen as they transition to self-directed learning.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Liberated Learners {{!}} What Is the North Star Model?|url = http://liberatedlearners.net/about/what-is-the-north-star-model/|website = liberatedlearners.net|access-date = 2016-02-20}}</ref> The center is funded through sliding-scale tuition and donations.
== History == [[Image:Russell Street School, Hadley MA.jpg|thumb|left|150px|<center>Russell Street School building in Hadley, Massachusetts</center>]]North Star was founded as Pathfinder Learning Center by Kenneth Danford and Joshua Hornick in 1996. After reading [[Grace Llewellyn]]'s book ''[[The Teenage Liberation Handbook]]'' they both quit their jobs as middle school teachers to create a center that would make what Llewellyn described possible for teenagers in their area.<ref name=":1" />
In 2002, the center was renamed North Star: Self-Directed Learning for Teens,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = School is optional - The story of North Star|url = http://schoolisoptional.org/the-story-of-north-star/|website = schoolisoptional.org|access-date = 2016-02-02}}</ref> and in 2007 the center moved into the historic Russell Street School building in [[Hadley, Massachusetts]].
In June, 2015, North Star moved to Sunderland due to safety concerns with the Russell Street building.<ref>{{Cite web|title = North Star to move from Hadley to Sunderland in June after 13 years in town|url = http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2015/02/north_star_to_move_from_hadley.html|website = masslive.com|access-date = 2016-02-02}}</ref>
== Program == Using homeschooling as a tool to get out of school, North Star works personally with each teen and their family to create an educational plan that is supported by North Star's staff and teachers. This customized plan consists of a staff adviser, parent conferences, and classes, tutorials, workshops, or tutoring if desired and available. North Star works with every interested family, regardless of ability to pay tuition or fees.<ref name=":0" />
Classes, tutorials, and workshops are taught by staff members, volunteers, or college students through [[Federal Work-Study Program|work-study]]. Classes are scheduled Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday, and the center is closed on Wednesdays and weekends. Attendance is non-compulsory and there are no required classes.
== The North Star model == Since 2010, a number of self-directed learning centers have opened in both the United States and Canada, using the approach and program pioneered by North Star. The centers are part of the Liberated Learners network which supports people to create centers based on the North Star model.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Robinson|first1=Ken|title=Creative Schools: The grassroots revolution that's transforming education|date=2015|publisher=Viking|location=New York, New York|isbn=978-0-670-01671-6|page=56}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.northstarteens.org/ The North Star website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eq1rXdDWXrM Ken Danford: School is Optional] at TEDxAmherstCollege, November 2013

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} "'''Preparedness 101: Zombie Apocalypse'''" is a [[blog]] post by the United States [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) that uses a [[zombie apocalypse]] metaphor to raise public awareness of [[Emergency management|emergency preparedness]].<ref name=Fox/> In a blog post titled "Preparedness 101: Zombie Apocalypse", the director of the CDC's Office of Public Health Preparedness and Response, [[Rear admiral|Rear Admiral]] [[Ali S. Khan]] writes: "Take a zombie apocalypse for example. That's right, I said z-o-m-b-i-e a-p-o-c-a-l-y-p-s-e. You may laugh now, but when it happens you'll be happy you read this, and hey, maybe you'll even learn a thing or two about how to prepare for a real emergency."<ref name=Fox/> Comparing the upcoming [[hurricane]] season and possible [[pandemic]]s to "flesh-eating zombies" from the [[horror film]] ''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' and the video game series ''[[Resident Evil]]'', Khan recommends Americans prepare for natural disasters as they would have prepared for "ravenous monsters".<ref name=Fox/>
== Inspiration ==
A week before the zombie apocalypse post, members of the CDC group responsible for preparedness of the public for [[natural disaster]]s and pandemics were working on the message anticipating the 2011 hurricane season.<ref name=WP/> Dave Daigle, associate director for communications, admitted that, "preparedness and public health are not the sexiest subjects."<ref name=WP/> Someone in the group remembered a [[Twitter|tweet]] about zombies in connection to the [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents|nuclear disaster in Japan]] resulting from the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. This provided the idea for the upcoming CDC post,<ref name=WP/> implemented on May 18, 2011 along with two tweets.<ref name=WP/> "The whole idea was, if you're prepared for a zombie apocalypse, you're prepared for pretty much anything," said Drew RN.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.skepticality.com/centers-zombie-control-prevention/ | work=Skepticality Podcast | title=Centers for Zombie Control and Prevention | date=2011-10-25 | accessdate=2014-03-08}}</ref>
== The blog post ==
The CDC's blog post included precautionary tips about zombies along with its usual tips for preparing an emergency kit, as well as emergency escape routes in case of an earthquake or hurricane. For example, after explaining how the public should be prepared "if zombies started appearing outside your doorstep", it continues: "You can also implement this plan if there is a flood, earthquake, or other emergency."<ref name=Atlantic/>
{{quote|Plan your evacuation route. When zombies are hungry they won't stop until they get food (i.e., brains), which means you need to get out of town fast! Plan where you would go and multiple routes you would take ahead of time so that the flesh eaters don't have a chance! This is also helpful when natural disasters strike and you have to take shelter fast.<ref name=Atlantic/>}}
Some commentators noted that May 21, 2011, [[2011 end times prediction|the date predicted by Harold Camping as the beginning of the end-times]], was several days after the blog post, though there was no mention of this speculation in the post itself.<ref name="ABC News - 20May2011 - Brains... brains...">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/05/20/3221851.htm|title=US agency posts zombie apocalypse survival tips |date=May 20, 2011 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)]] |accessdate=May 21, 2011 }}</ref>
==CDC website crash==
The blog post generated [[Internet traffic]] that eventually crashed the CDC website.<ref name=SA/> Usually, CDC blog posts get traffic between 1,000 and 3,000 hits per week.<ref name=CBS/> 30,000 hits were reported by the evening of May 18.<ref name=SA/><ref name=CBS/> The post, oriented at "a young, media-savvy demographic", was read by so many that "by Thursday, it was a trending topic on Twitter".<ref name=SA/> Initially the tweet with the [[tagline]] ''If you're ready for a zombie apocalypse, then you're ready for any emergency'' got 12,000 followers; overnight the number of followers increased to 1.2 million, or 100 times the initial number.<ref name=WP/> Mr. Daigle said that the number of the followers of the CDC's zombie apocalypse tweets was comparable to the number of followers of the [[wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton]]: "We were trending yesterday! Things like the Royal Wedding trend. Not the CDC."<ref name=WP/>
[[Robert Pestronk]], executive director of the [[National Association of County and City Health Officials]] agreed that "The 'Zombie Apocalypse' scenario was a great way of getting information out so people can understand the need for preparedness."<ref name=ABC/>
==Reaction== Daigle said people were visiting the CDC's blog and following CDC tweets because they were mostly interested in zombies and were asking what weapons the agency would recommend to fight zombies. Khan's response to this inquiry was, "remember, we're a public-health center, so we're not going to recommend weapons. We'll leave that to the law-enforcement folks."<ref name=Atlantic1/> Chris Good from ''[[The Atlantic]]'' saw the absence of weapons recommendations (albeit, tongue-in-cheek) as a "downside to the CDC's warning" and wrote: "If a zombie apocalypse does happen—and this is important—do not follow the CDC's guidelines as your only course of action. The CDC zombie plan includes no mention of shotguns, torches, [[hot-wiring]] cars, seeking high ground, traveling at night vs. day, or really any worthwhile strategy for keeping zombies out of your house. Parts of it are good, but it probably would serve the public better in the event of, for instance, a hurricane."<ref name=Atlantic1/>
Others were concerned about [[taxpayer]] money being used for the CDC's budget; the CDC assured the public there was no additional cost for their zombie apocalypse blog post.<ref name=CBS1/>
Bill Gentry with the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Public Health|UNC-Chapel Hill School of Public Health]] said that the CDC deserves credit for trying something different, "but that doesn't mean the agency should start using vampires to promote vaccinations or space aliens to warn about the dangers of smoking."<ref name=Boomerang/>
==Video contest== The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] announced a contest for the most creative and effective videos covering preparedness for a zombie apocalypse or apocalypse of any kind. In this video contest, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] challenged contestants to upload videos to YouTube demonstrating how they are preparing for emergency situations such as [[flood]]s, earthquakes, hurricanes and zombie attacks.<ref name=WSJ/>
==Graphic novel== {{Infobox book | italic title = Preparedness 101: Zombie Pandemic <!--(see above)--> | name = Preparedness 101: Zombie Pandemic | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = {{plainlist| * Maggie Silver * James Archer * Bob Hobbs * Alissa Eckert * Mark Conner * Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.) }} | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = Bob Hobbs | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = [[Graphic novel]], Government publication | set_in = | published = | publisher = Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | publisher2 = U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services | pub_date = {{start date|2011}} | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 40 | awards = | isbn = | oclc = 854576760 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} In October 2011, the CDC published a ''Zombie Pandemic'' graphic novella created by fantasy artist Bob Hobbs (layouts, pencils and inks), Alissa Eckert (coloring) and Mark Conner (lettering, assembly).<ref>https://www.cdc.gov/phpr/zombie/novel.htm</ref>
==Analyzing results== The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] is planning to run a survey to find out how many of the blog's readers actually followed the tips and made recommended preparations for natural disasters, zombie attacks and other emergency situations.<ref name=Atlantic1/><ref name=CBS1/>
== See also == {{Zombies}} * [[List of incidents of cannibalism]] * ''[[The Zombie Survival Guide]]'' * [[Zombie Squad]]
==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= <ref name=Fox>{{Cite web |title=CDC Warns Public to Prepare for 'Zombie Apocalypse'|author=Joshua Rhett Miller |url=http://www.foxnews.com/health/2011/05/18/cdc-warns-public-prepare-zombie-apocalypse/ |publisher=[[FoxNews]] |date= May 18, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520111414/http://www.foxnews.com/health/2011/05/18/cdc-warns-public-prepare-zombie-apocalypse/| archivedate= May 20, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
<ref name=SA>{{Cite news |title=Zombie Apocalypse' Campaign Crashes CDC Website |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=zombie-apocalypse-campaign-crash |work=[[Scientific American]] |date= May 19, 2011|accessdate=May 20, 2011}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=ABC>{{Cite web |title=Will Budget Cuts Leave Us Unprepared for Zombie Apocalypse? |author=KIM CAROLLO |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/federal-funding-cuts-put-us-risk-zombie-attack/story?id=13638676 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date= May 19, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=WP>{{Cite news |title=Zombie apocalypse a coup for CDC emergency team |author=Melissa Bell web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/zombie-apocalypse-a-coup-for-the-cdc-emergency-team/2011/05/20/AFPj3l7G_blog.html |series=BlogPost |work=The Washington Post |date= May 20, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=CBS>{{Cite news |title=CDC's 'zombie apocalypse' advice an Internet hit |url=http://www.cbs8.com/story/14688932/cdcs-zombie-apocalypse-advice-an-internet-hit|publisher=[[CBS]]|date= May 21, 2011 |accessdate=May 21, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=CBS1>{{Cite news |title=CDC Offers Tips On How To Prepare For The 'Zombie Apocalypse' |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2011/05/20/cdc-offers-advice-on-how-to-prepare-for-the-zombie-apocalypse/ |publisher=[[CBS]]|date= May 20, 2011 |accessdate=May 21, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=Atlantic>{{Cite news |title=Apocalyptic Economics: Whether Zombies or Rapture, Be Prepared |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2011/05/apocalyptic-economics-whether-zombies-or-rapture-be-prepared/239234/|author=Daniel Indiviglio|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date= May 20, 2011 |accessdate=May 21, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=Atlantic1>{{Cite news |title=Why Did the CDC Develop a Plan for a Zombie Apocalypse?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2011/05/why-did-the-cdc-develop-a-plan-for-a-zombie-apocalypse/239246/|author=Chris Good |publisher=[[The Atlantic]]|date= May 20, 2011 |accessdate=May 21, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=WSJ>{{Cite news |title=CDC's Zombie Apocalypse Juggernaut: Next Up, a Video Contest|author=Betsy McKay|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/health/2011/05/20/cdcs-zombie-apocalypse-juggernaut-next-up-a-video-contest/?mod=WSJBlog|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] blog|date= May 20, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2011}}</ref>
<ref name=Boomerang>{{Cite news|title=CDC's 'zombie apocalypse' advice an Internet hit |url=http://www.laramieboomerang.com/articles/2011/05/22/ap/health/us_med_cdc_zombies.txt |author=Chris Good |publisher=[[Laramie Boomerang]] |date=May 22, 2011 |accessdate=May 22, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> }}
==External links== *[https://www.cdc.gov/phpr/zombie/index.htm CDC Zombie Preparedness articles]

'''The Princes' School''' in [[Riyadh]], [[Saudi Arabia]], was established by King [[Ibn Saud]] specifically to ensure a high level of education for members of the [[House of Saud]] and sons of other foremost Saudis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.babnet.net/en_detail-1405.asp|website=Babnet|title=Biography of King Fahd bin Abdul Aziz Al-Saud |accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> Early in the Ibn Saud newly established country the [[Council of Senior Scholars (Saudi Arabia)|Council of Senior Scholars]] or [[ulema]] thought education should only involve studying the [[Qur'an]] and [[shari'a]] law. The school was only conducted within [[Royal court]].<ref name=skyhourse>{{cite book|last1=Bray|first1=Barbara|last2=Darlow|first2=Michael|title=Ibn Saud: The Desert Warrior Who Created the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia|date=13 December 2013|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|location=USA|isbn=9781620874141|pages=608}}</ref>
==Alumni== * [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]], King of Saudi Arabia<ref>[http://www.riyadh.gov.sa/en/Pages/Princes/Princes.aspx?ItemId=5 "His royal highness Prince Salman bin Abdulaziz"]. ''Ministry of Interior''. Retrieved 12 May 2012.</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=May 2011}} {{no footnotes|date=May 2011}} {{advert|date=April 2012}} {{cleanup|reason=information is out of date|date=April 2015}} {{peacock|date=April 2015}} }} {{Infobox company |type = [[Corporation]] |name = SEAMEO RESCAM |logo = recsam logo.jpg |foundation = 1967 |location = [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]] |area_served = Educational services in:

and beyond |key_people = Dr. Azian T.S. Abdullah, Director |industry = Education |homepage = {{URL|http://www.recsam.edu.my/}} }} [[Image:recsam2.jpg|thumb|right|Regional Centre for Education in Science and Mathematics.]] The '''Regional Centre for Education in Science and Mathematics (RECSAM)''' is a [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] educational [[corporation]] headquartered in [[Penang, Malaysia]]. It is one of the founding sister centres of SEAMEO, the [[Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organisation]]. SEAMEO was established on 30 November 1965 as a chartered international organisation whose purpose is to promote co-operation in education, science and culture in the Southeast Asian region. Since its inception in 1967, RECSAM has assisted in the principal development of educational manpower and served as a catalyst for the advancement of science and mathematics education at the primary and secondary school levels for its member countries, namely: [[Brunei Darussalam]], [[Cambodia]], [[Indonesia]], [[Laos|Lao Peoples' Democratic Republic]], [[Malaysia]], [[Myanmar]], the [[Philippines]], [[Singapore]], [[Thailand]], [[Timor Leste]] and [[Vietnam]]. RECSAM has also been offering teachers and educators training opportunities to improve their skills and make them more adaptable to the changing educational environment. To date, well over six thousand teachers and key educators have taken the Centre’s regular courses.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} ==Training== ===Regular Courses=== Development of skills and knowledge of key teachers and educators of the Southeast Asia has been the core business of RECSAM. The Centre will continuously conduct regular courses for participants coming from 10 SEAMEO member countries. From FY2006/2007 the Centre hopes to receive participants from Timor Leste, a newly independent country who has joined SEAMEO. The Centre will conduct 27 regular courses in the coming three years. Each course will be of 4 week duration. The proposed training courses for the next three fiscal years are extracted from RECSAM's 8th Five Year Plan (FY 2005/2006 – 2009/2010). The topics and outlines of these projects have been identified through an elaborate process of reviewing current and future trends in science and mathematics education, the needs of SEAMEO Member Countries and prioritising them according to their importance. ===In-country Courses=== Besides regular courses, the Centre conducts in-country courses whereby the professionals from the Centre will train participants from the respective countries at their own country. ===Diploma and Masters Programme=== RECSAM started this programme in 2006 with [[Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia]] and the first batch of participants was from [[Bandung, Indonesia]]. This programme, a Post Graduate Certificate of Education in ICT leading to a Master of Education in IT & Resource, takes 11 months to complete. This programme will be a twinned programme with [[Deakin University]] in [[Australia]]. ===Customised Courses=== In 2005, a group of 5 [[Kenya]]n educators participated in our{{who|date=April 2012}} regular course as fee paying participants. Since the course was observed to be very relevant to them, the Centre was requested by JICA, the sponsor, to conduct more courses for the Kenyan. A contract with JICA has been signed to train the Kenyan educators for the next three years. In 2006, the Centre received 40 Kenyan educators to attend the customised courses. More customised course will be conducted if there is demand from local, regional and international participants. In 2007, another 40 Kenyan educators to attend customised courses for Math & Science at the Center. However, for the Ugandans, a customised course was held for the Science group. In the beginning of 2008, participants from [[Aceh, Indonesia]] were here. ==Research and Development== The Centre recognises that [[research and development]] is a critical area that needs to be addressed to enhance the quality and relevance of its training programmes. Research and Development Division undertakes various programmes and activities which are focused on Conduct of Research, Development of Resources, Dissemination and Review and Evaluation. At most, two researches will be conducted a year which will include a classroom-based research and a long range research which may focus on policy formulation or towards the enhancement of teaching and learning of science and mathematics and integration of ICT. The possible research topics are clustered along the following major areas:- * Thinking and Meaningful Understanding in Science and Mathematics * Classroom Learning Environment in Science and Mathematics * Effective Teaching and Learning Strategies * Assessing Teaching and Learning in Mathematics * ICT in the Science and Mathematics Classrooms * Impact and Evaluation Studies To further enhance the relevance of its programme, RECSAM has also taken the initiative to promote Research and Development activities among students and also to encourage the setting up of Research and Development centres in the schools. Fourteen schools around Penang have been chosen to be partner schools in this programme. The MoU has been signed with the Education Department of Penang witnessed by the Principals, Headmasters or representatives of the respective schools. ==Commemoration ceremony of RECSAM's 40th Anniversary 2007== [[Image:Officiating.jpg|thumb|right|H.E. Dato' Seri Hishammuddin Tun Hussein, Minister of Education Malaysia officiating the ceremony on 5 September 2007 with a student while looking on is the center director, Dr Azian T.S. Abdullah.]] The theme song of the anniversary was titled '''SEAMEO RECSAM''', composed by '''Ahmad Ramli''' with lyrics written by '''Dr. Azian Abdullah'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.recsam.edu.my Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Recsam}} [[Category:Education in Malaysia|Penang]] [[Category:Penang]]

{{Use Indian English|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{infobox museum |name= Raman Science Centre and Planetarium |image= |established= 1992 |location= [[Nagpur]] |visitors= 1,44,40,963(approx.)(till date) |director= [[Narayan Ramdas Iyer]]. |publictransit= |website= [http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/RSCN/rscn.htm Website] |network= }} The '''Raman Science Centre and Raman Planetarium Complex''' at [[Nagpur]] is an interactive [[science centre]] affiliated with [[Mumbai]]'s [[Nehru Science Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/nsc_family.htm|title=satellite units|publisher=www.nehrusciencecentre.org|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917035503/http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/nsc_family.htm|archivedate=17 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} The centre was developed to promote a scientific attitude, portray the growth of science and technology and their applications in industry and human welfare, and hold science exhibits. The centre is named after famous [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Nobel Prize]] winner Indian [[physicist]] [[Chandrasekhara Venkata Raman]]. The Raman Science Centre was inaugurated on 7 March 1992 and the [[planetarium]] was started on 5 January 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/RSCN/rscnGenInfo.htm|title=General Information|publisher=www.nehrusciencecentre.org|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618023908/http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/RSCN/rscnGenInfo.htm|archivedate=18 June 2008|df=dmy-all}} The centre is located opposite Gandhi Sagar Lake in the heart of Nagpur. Between 1 April 2014 and 31 March 2015 the Centre recorded a visitor count of 582,962.{{cite web|url=http://ncsm.gov.in/visitorStat.aspx|title=no. of Visitors|publisher=ncsm.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522084746/http://www.ncsm.gov.in/visitorStat.aspx|archivedate=22 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} The centre is part of the [[National Council of Science Museums]] (NCSM), India which is also the largest network of science centres/museums under a single administrative umbrella in the world.{{cite web|url=http://ncsm.gov.in/index.aspx|title=ncsm.gov.in|publisher=ncsm.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522082610/http://www.ncsm.gov.in/index.aspx|archivedate=22 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} NCSM rates the centre as regional level and it has a total floor area of 4333 sq meters.{{cite web|url=http://ncsm.gov.in/units1.aspx|title=Units under NCSM|publisher=ncsm.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618221959/http://ncsm.gov.in/units1.aspx|archivedate=18 June 2008|df=dmy-all}} [[File:Raman Science Centre and Planetarium.jpg|thumb|Raman Science Centre and Planetarium]] == Activities == The centre carries out numerous programs to spread science and technology knowledge amongst the general public.{{cite web|url=http://www.rscbagpur.gov.in.|title=activities|publisher=www.rscnagpur.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The centre has started innovation centre from 14 February 2017, that gives opportunities to students, who are dedicated to science. The centre along with local NGO Hirwai gives the ''Green Finger Award'' to create awareness about the environment amongst school children.{{cite web|url=http://hirwai.org/Hirvariaward.php|title=hirwai|publisher=hirwai.org|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726151219/http://hirwai.org/Hirvariaward.php|archivedate=26 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} In August 2007, the information and communication technology gallery was opened{{cite web|url=http://ncsm.gov.in/infocom.aspx|title=Information & Communication Technology|publisher=ncsm.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618221435/http://ncsm.gov.in/infocom.aspx|archivedate=18 June 2008|df=dmy-all}} where [[ISRO]] Chairman Madhavan Nair declared that India will send astronauts in space by 2015.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/India/India_will_send_astronaut_into_space_by_2015_ISRO_chief/articleshow/2254060.cms|title=India will send astronaut into space by 2015: ISRO chief|date=3 August 2007|publisher=timesofindia.indiatimes.com|accessdate=2008-06-06}} The centre currently has 4 different interactive galleries, an Innovation Centre, a Science on a Sphere Show and a 133-seat planetarium,{{cite web|url=http://ncsm.gov.in/exibits_6.aspx|title=planetarium|publisher=ncsm.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618221431/http://ncsm.gov.in/exibits_6.aspx|archivedate=18 June 2008|df=dmy-all}} fun science, a prehistoric Animal Park and more.{{cite web|url=http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/RSCN/rscnExhiGal.htm|title=galleries|publisher=www.nehrusciencecentre.org|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618023903/http://www.nehrusciencecentre.org/RSCN/rscnExhiGal.htm|archivedate=18 June 2008|df=dmy-all}} The centre also holds science lectures, science film shows and [[3-D film|3-dimensional science shows]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rscnagpur.gov.in|title=Shows|publisher=www.rscnagpur.gov.in|accessdate=2008-06-06}} The centre also organises activities like planet watching and other celestial phenomena for citizens.{{cite web|url=http://www.nagpurplus.com/fullStory.asp?articleID=NAGP3ART8232006|title=Planet observation|publisher=www.nagpurplus.com|accessdate=2008-06-08}}. The centre has 1,44,94,443 visitors since 1987. == General information == '''Schedule of the science centre''' * All seven days a week: 9:30 am to 6:00 pm
'''Charges''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Visit ! General public ! Students in organised school groups |- | Science Centre | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 25/- | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 10/- |- | Planetarium | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 50/- | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 25/- |- | Science on a Sphere | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 25/- |- | 3D theatre | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 20/- | [[Indian rupee|INR]] 10/- |} == References == {{reflist}} {{Nagpur}} {{coord missing|Maharashtra}} [[Category:1992 establishments in India]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Nagpur]] [[Category:Science museums in India]] [[Category:Planetaria]] [[Category:Museums established in 1992]] [[Category:Museums in Maharashtra]] [[Category:Science centres in India]]

page.title: Secondary School Mathematics Curriculum Improvement Study

revision.text:
The '''Secondary School Mathematics Curriculum Improvement Study''' (SSMCIS) was the name of an American [[mathematics education]] program that stood for both the name of a curriculum and the name of the project that was responsible for developing curriculum materials. It is considered part of the second round of initiatives in the "[[New Math]]" movement of the 1960s.<ref name="nyt-fehr-obit"/><ref name="fey-1978"/> The program was led by Howard F. Fehr, a professor at [[Columbia University Teachers College]].
The program's signature goal was to create a unified treatment of mathematics and eliminate the traditional separate per-year studies of [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[trigonometry]], and so forth, that was typical of American secondary schools.<ref name="walmsley">{{cite book | title=A History of the 'New Mathematics' Movement and Its Relationship with Current Mathematical Reform | first=Angela Lynn Evans | last=Walmsley | publisher=[[University Press of America]] | location=Lanham, Maryland | year= 2003 | isbn=0-7618-2511-8 | pages=30, 68}}</ref> Instead, the treatment unified those branches by studying fundamental concepts such as [[Set (mathematics)|sets]], [[Relation (mathematics)|relations]], [[Operation (mathematics)|operations]], and [[Mapping (mathematics)|mappings]], and fundamental structures such as [[Group (mathematics)|groups]], [[Ring (mathematics)|rings]], [[Field (mathematics)|fields]], and [[vector space]]s. The SSMCIS program produced six courses' worth of class material, intended for grades 7 through 12, in textbooks called '''''Unified Modern Mathematics'''''. Some 25,000 students took SSMCIS courses nationwide during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
==Background== The program was led by Howard F. Fehr, a professor at [[Columbia University Teachers College]] who was internationally known and had published numerous mathematics textbooks and hundreds of articles about mathematics teaching.<ref name="nyt-fehr-obit">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/07/obituaries/dr-howard-f-fehr-author-helped-start-system-of-new-math.html | title=Dr. Howard F. Fehr: Author Helped Start System of New Math | first=Walter H. | last=Waggoner | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 7, 1982}}</ref> In 1961 he had been the principal author of the 246-page report "New Thinking in School Mathematics", which held that [[traditional mathematics|traditional teaching of mathematics]] approaches did not meet the needs of the new technical society being entered into or of the current language of mathematicians and scientists.<ref name="nyt-fehr-obit"/> Fehr considered the separation of mathematical study into separate years of distinct subjects to be an American failing that followed an educational model two hundred years old.<ref name="fehr-1974"/>
The new curriculum was inspired by the seminar reports from the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] in the early 1960s<ref name="fehr-1974"/> and by the [[Cambridge Conference on School Mathematics]] (1963), which also inspired the [[Comprehensive School Mathematics Program]].<ref name="walmsley"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mathcurriculumcenter.org/PDFS/CCM/summaries/cambridge_summary.pdf | title=Goals for School Mathematics | publisher=Center for the Study of Mathematics Curriculum | year=2004 | accessdate=September 13, 2013}}</ref> There were some interactions among these initiatives in the early stages,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.imacs.org/imacsadmin/parser?pageid=37 | title=Burt Kaufman | publisher=Institute for Mathematics & Computer Science | accessdate=September 13, 2013}}</ref> and the development of SSMCIS was part of a general wave of cooperation in the mathematics education reform movement between Europe and the U.S.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.icmihistory.unito.it/portrait/steiner.php | title=The first century of the International Commission on Mathematical Instruction (1908–2008) – History of ICMI – Hans Georg Steiner | first=Gert | last=Schubring | publisher=[[University of Turin]] | accessdate=September 13, 2013}}</ref>
==Curriculum == {{Quote box|width=27%|align=right|quote="The construction is to be free of any restrictions of traditional content or sequence."|source=<small>—From the initial announcement of the curriculum work of the SSMCIS <ref name="fehr-1966">{{cite journal | first=H. F. | last=Fehr | title=Secondary School Mathematics Curriculum Improvement Study | journal=[[The American Mathematical Monthly]] | volume=73 | issue=5 |date=May 1966 | page=533 | doi=10.2307/2315483| jstor=2315483 }}</ref></small>}}
Work on the SSMCIS program began in 1965<ref name="walmsley"/> and took place mainly at Teachers College.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Fehr was the director of the project from 1965 to 1973.<ref name="nyt-fehr-obit"/> The principal consultants in the initial stages and subsequent yearly planning sessions were [[Marshall H. Stone]] of the [[University of Chicago]], [[Albert W. Tucker]] of [[Princeton University]], [[Edgar Lorch]] of [[Columbia University]], and Meyer Jordan of [[Brooklyn College]].<ref name="fehr-1974">{{cite journal | first=Howard F. | last=Fehr | title=The Secondary School Mathematics Curriculum Improvement Study: A Unified Mathematics Program | journal=The Mathematics Teacher | volume=67 | issue=1 |date=January 1974 | pages=25–33}}</ref> The program was targeted at the junior high and high school level and the 15–20 percent best students in a grade.<ref name="walmsley"/><ref name="fehr-1969"/>
Funding for the initiative began with the U.S. [[Office of Education]] and covered the development first three courses produced; the last three courses produced, as well as teacher training, were funded by the [[National Science Foundation]] and by Teachers College itself.<ref name="curdev-math"/><ref name="umm-v-ii"/> The scope and sequence of the curriculum was developed by eighteen mathematicians from the U.S. and Europe in 1966 and subsequently refined in experimental course material by mathematical educators with high school level teaching experience.<ref name="fehr-1969">{{cite journal | first=H. F. | last=Fehr | first2=James | last2=Fey | title=The Secondary School Mathematics Curriculum Improvement Study | journal=[[The American Mathematical Monthly]] | volume=76 | issue=10 |date=December 1969 | pages=1132–1137 | doi=10.2307/2317192}}</ref> By 1971, some thirty-eight contributors to course materials were identified, eight from Teachers College, four from Europe, one from Canada, and the rest from various other universities (and a couple of high schools) in the United States.<ref name="umm-v-ii"/> Fehr did not do much curriculum development himself, but rather recruited and led the others and organized the whole process.<ref name="curdev-math-79">Howson, Keitel, and Kilpatrick, ''Curriculum Development in Mathematics'', pp. 79–81.</ref> Graduate students from the Department of Mathematical Education at Teachers College also served each year in various capacities on the SSMCIS program.<ref name="curdev-math"/>
The central idea of the program was to organize mathematics not by algebra, geometry, etc., but rather to unify those branches by studying the fundamental concepts of [[Set (mathematics)|sets]], [[Relation (mathematics)|relations]], [[Operation (mathematics)|operations]], and [[Mapping (mathematics)|mappings]], and fundamental structures such as [[Group (mathematics)|groups]], [[Ring (mathematics)|rings]], [[Field (mathematics)|fields]], and [[vector space]]s.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Other terms used for this approach included "global" or "integrated";<ref name="lhs-cos"/> Fehr himself spoke of a "spiral" or "helical" development, and wrote of "the spirit of global organization that is at the heart of the SSMCIS curriculum – important mathematical systems unified by a core of fundamental concepts and structures common to all.<ref name="fehr-1969"/>
For example, as the courses progressed, the concept of mappings were used to describe, and visually illustrate, the traditionally disparate topics of [[Translation (geometry)|translation]], [[Reflection (mathematics)|line reflection]], [[Probability space|probability of an event]], [[trigonometric functions]], [[isomorphism]] and [[complex number]]s, and [[Mathematical analysis|analysis]] and [[Linear map|linear mappings]].<ref name="fehr-1974"/> Traditional subjects were broken up, such that the course material for each year included some material related to algebra, some to geometry, and so forth.<ref name="fehr-1974"/><!-- TODO ... more descr and examples -->
Even when abstract concepts were being introduced, they were introduced in concrete, intuitive forms, especially at the younger levels.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Logical proofs were introduced early on and built in importance as the years developed.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> At least one year of university-level mathematics education was incorporated into the later courses.<ref name="walmsley"/> Solving traditional applications problems was de-emphasized, especially in the earlier courses, but the intent of the project was to make up for that with its focus on real numbers in measurements, computer programming, and probability and statistics.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> In particular, the last of these was a pronounced element of SSMCIS, with substantial material on it present in all six courses, from measures of [[statistical dispersion]] to [[combinatorics]] to [[Bayes' theorem]] and more.<ref name="fehr-1974"/>
The curriculum that SSMCIS devised had influences from earlier reform work in Europe,<ref name="walmsley"/> going back to the [[Bourbaki group]]'s work in France in the 1930s and the ''Synopses for Modern Secondary School Mathematics'' published in Paris in 1961.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Indeed, most European secondary schools were teaching a more integrated approach.<ref name="nys-integrated"/> Also, this was one of several American efforts to address a particularly controversial issue, the teaching of a full year of [[Euclidean geometry]] in secondary school.<ref name="acmdl">{{cite conference | first=Joseph K. | last=McAdams | first2=Arlan R. |last2=DeKock | title=Computer graphics as an aid to teaching geometric transformations | conference=SIGCSE '76 Proceedings of the ACM SIGCSE-SIGCUE Technical Symposium on Computer Science and Education | publisher=[[Association for Computing Machinery]] | location=New York | <!-- doi=10.1145/800107.803463 --> | pages=137–143}}</ref> Like many of the others, it did this by teaching [[Transformation geometry|geometric transformations]] as a unifying approach between algebra and geometry.<ref name="acmdl"/>
Regardless of all these influences and other projects, the SSMCIS study group considered its work unique in scope and breadth, and Fehr wrote that "nowhere [else] had a total 7–12 unified mathematics program been designed, produced, and tested."<ref name="fehr-1969"/> It was thus considered one of the more radical of the reform efforts lumped under the "New Math" label.<ref name="kline">{{cite book | first=Morris | last=Kline | authorlink=Morris Kline | title=Why Johnny Can't Add: The Failure of the New Math | publisher=[[Vintage Books]] | location= | year=1974 | isbn=0394719816 | at=Chapter 3}}</ref> Moreover, Fehr believed that the SSMCIS could not just improve students' thinking in mathematics, but in all subjects, by "develop[ing] the capacity of the human mind for the observation, selection, generalization, abstraction, and construction of models for use in the other disciplines."<ref name="fehr-1974"/>
==Materials== [[Image:Unified Modern Mathematics Course III Part 1 cover.jpg|thumb|223px|right|upright|The paper covers of the course books had a different color for each of the six courses: light blue, yellow, light green (here), red, blue, dark red.]]
The course books put out by SSMCIS were titled ''Unified Modern Mathematics'', and labeled as Course I through Course VI, with the two volumes in each year labeled as Part I and Part II.<ref name="umm-v-ii">{{cite book | title=Unified Modern Mathematics: Course V: Part II | publisher=[[Teachers College, Columbia University]] | location=New York | edition=Revised | year=1971}}</ref> Materials for the next year's course were prepared each year, thus keeping up with the early adoption programs underway.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Using largely [[formative evaluation]] methods for gaining teacher feedback,<ref name="curdev-math-196"/> revised versions were put out after the first year's teaching experience.<ref name="curdev-math"/> By 1973, the revised version of all six courses had been completed.<ref name="curdev-math">{{cite book | title=Curriculum Development in Mathematics | type=Paperback | first=Geoffrey |last=Howson |first2=Christine |last2=Keitel |first3= Jeremy |last3=Kilpatrick | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] | location= | year=1982 | pages=38–41}}</ref> The first three volumes were put into the public domain for any organization to use.<ref name="fehr-1974"/>
The pages of the books were formatted by typewriter, augmented by some mathematical symbols and inserted graphs, bound in paper, and published by Teachers College itself.<ref name="umm-v-ii"/> A more polished hardcover version of Courses I through IV was put out in subsequent years by [[Addison-Wesley]]; these were adaptations made by Fehr and others and targeted to students with a broader range of mathematical ability.<ref name="curdev-math"/>
[[Computer programming]] on [[Time-sharing|time-shared computer systems]] was included in the curriculum both for its own importance and for understanding numerical methods.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> The first course introduced [[flow chart]]s and the notion of [[algorithm]]s.<ref name="umm-i-ii">{{cite book | title=Unified Modern Mathematics: Course I: Part II | publisher=[[Teachers College, Columbia University]] | location=New York | edition=Revised | year=1967}}</ref> The beginning portion of the fourth-year course was devoted to introducing the [[BASIC]] programming language, with an emphasis on fundamental [[control flow]] statements, continued use of flow charts for design, and [[numerical programming]] applications. Interactive teletype interfaces on slow and erratic [[dial-up modem|dial-up connections]], with troublesome [[paper tape]] for offline storage, was the typical physical environment.<ref name="umm-iv-i">{{cite book | title=Unified Modern Mathematics: Course IV: Part I | publisher=[[Teachers College, Columbia University]] | location=New York | edition=Revised | year=1970}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Adoption== Starting in 1966, teachers from nine junior high and high schools, mostly in the [[New York metropolitan area]], began getting training in the study program at Teachers College.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Such training was crucial since few junior high or high school teachers knew all the material that would be introduced.<ref name="curdev-math-79"/> They then returned to their schools and began teaching the experimental courses,<ref name="fehr-1969"/> two teachers per grade.<ref name="curdev-math"/> For instance, [[Leonia High School]], which incorporated grades 8–12 (since there was no middle school then), called the program "Math X" for experimental, with individual courses called Math 8X, Math 9X, etc.<ref name="lhs-cos">{{cite book | title=Program of Studies: 1970–1971 | publisher=[[Leonia High School]] | location=Leonia, New Jersey | year=1970 | page=21}}</ref> [[Hunter College High School]] used it as the basis for its Extended Honors Program; the school's description stated that the program "includes many advanced topics and requires extensive preparation and a considerable commitment of time to the study of mathematics."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hchs.hunter.cuny.edu/images/uploads/CourseOutline_Math7.pdf | title=Mathematics: Departmental Philosophy | publisher=[[Hunter College High School]] | accessdate=September 13, 2013}} </ref> Students were periodically given standardized tests to make sure there was no decline in performance due to the unusual organization of material.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Some 400 students were involved in this initial phase.<ref name="fehr-1974"/>
Because the program was so different from standard U.S. mathematics curricula, it was quite difficult to students to enter after the first year; students did, however, sometimes drop out of it and return to standard courses.<ref name="curdev-math"/> As teaching the program was a specialized activity, teachers tended to move along from each grade to the next with their students, and so it was typical for students to have one of the same two teachers, or even the same teacher, for five or six years in a row.<ref name="curdev-math"/>
More teachers were added in 1968 and 1969 and the [[University of Maryland]] and [[University of Arizona]] were added as teaching sites.<ref name="fehr-1969"/> Eighteen schools in [[Los Angeles]] adopted SSMCIS in what was called the Accelerated Mathematics Instruction program; some 2,500 gifted students took part.<ref name="la-ami">{{cite journal | title=New Programs | first=Robert J. | last=Kansky | first2=Arthur A. | last2=Hiatt | first3=Mary Margaret |last3=Odom | journal= The Mathematics Teacher | volume=67 | issue= 8 |date=December 1974 | page= 729}}</ref> By 1971, teacher education programs were being conducted in places like [[Austin Peay State University]] in [[Tennessee]], which was attended by junior high school teachers from seventeen states and one foreign country.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KONHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F4AMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4830,1672755 | title=Math Teacher Taking Course | newspaper=[[The Victoria Advocate]] | location=Victoria, Texas | date=August 10, 1971 | page=3A}}</ref> <!-- also https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1WNhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xKAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1868,5399869 but seems like a pretty confused account --> By 1974, Fehr stated that 25,000 students were taking SSMCIS courses across the U.S.<ref name="fehr-1974"/>
==Results== [[Image:Unified Modern Mathematics Course 1 Teachers Commentary cover.jpg|thumb|175px|right|upright|Teacher's guides were also available for SSMCIS.]]
The Secondary School Mathematics Curriculum Improvement Study program did show some success in its educational purpose.<ref name="walmsley"/> A study of the Los Angeles program found that SSMCIS-taught students had a better attitude toward their program than did students using [[School Mathematics Study Group]] courses (another "New Math" initiative) or traditional courses.<ref name="la-ami"/> In [[New York State]] schools, special examinations were given to tenth and eleventh grade SSMCIS students in lieu of the standard [[Regents Examinations]]<ref name="fehr-1974"/> due to a mismatch in curriculum.<ref name="curdev-math-196">Howson, Keitel, and Kilpatrick, ''Curriculum Development in Mathematics'', pp. 196–197.</ref> However, SSMCIS was one of the direct inspirations for the [[New York State Education Department]], in the late 1970s and 1980s, adopting an integrated, three-year mathematics curriculum for all its students, combining algebra, geometry, and trigonometry with an increased emphasis in probability and statistics.<ref name="nys-integrated">{{cite journal | title=An Integrated Approach for Secondary School Mathematics | first=Fredric | last=Paul | journal=[[The Mathematics Teacher]] | volume= 79 | issue= 4 |date=April 1986 | pages= 236–238 }}</ref><ref name="curdev-math"/>
Given the differences in subject matter and approach, how SSMCIS-taught students would perform on [[College Entrance Examination Board]] tests became a major concern of parents and students and teachers.<ref name="curdev-math-196"/> A 1973 report compared the test performance of such students with those from traditional mathematics curricula. It found that the SSMCIS students did better on the mathematics portion of the [[PSAT/NMSQT|Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test (PSAT)]], even when matched for background and performance on the verbal portion. It also found that SSMCIS students did just as well on the [[SAT Subject Test in Mathematics Level 2|Mathematics Level II Achievement Test]] as traditional students taking college preparatory courses or, indeed, as college freshmen taking introductory calculus courses.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED081847 | title=Performance of SSMCIS-Trained Students on College Board Mathematics Examinations | last=Williams | first=S. Irene | last2= Jones | first2=Chancey O. | publisher=Test Development Report | year=1973}}</ref> Another study found SSMCIS students well prepared for the mathematics portion of the regular [[SAT|Scholastic Aptitude Test]].<ref>{{cite journal | title=An Overview of the Mathematics Achievement Tests Offered in the Admissions Testing Program of the College Entrance Examination Board | first=Chancey O. | last=Jones | first2=Mildred R. | last2=Rowen | first3=Howard E. | last3=Taylor | journal=The Mathematics Teacher | volume=70 | issue= 3 |date=March 1977 | pages= 197–208}}</ref>
However, SSMCIS developed slowly.<ref name="kline"/> Funding became an issue,<ref name="record"/> and indeed it was never funded as well as some other mathematics curriculum efforts had been.<ref name="curdev-math"/> Despite the federal funding source, there was no centralized, national focal point in the U.S. for curriculum changes – such as some European countries had – and that made adoption of SSMCIS innovations a harder task.<ref name="curdev-math-45">Howson, Keitel, and Kilpatrick, ''Curriculum Development in Mathematics'', pp. 45–47.</ref> By the mid-1970s there was a growing backlash against the "New Math" movement, spurred in part by a perceived decline in standardized test scores and by [[Morris Kline]]'s critical book ''Why Johnny Can't Add: The Failure of the New Math''.<ref name="fey-1978">{{cite journal | first=James T. | last=Fey | title=Change in Mathematics Education Since the Late 1950's – Ideas and Realisation U.S.A. | journal=[[Educational Studies in Mathematics]] | volume=9 | issue=3 |date=August 1978 | pages=339–353 | doi=10.1007/bf00241036}}</ref> Many reform efforts had underestimated the difficulty of getting the public and the mathematics educational community to believe that major changes were really necessary, especially for secondary school programs where college entrance performance was always the key concern of administrators.<ref name="fey-1978"/> Federal funding for curriculum development also came under attack from [[Conservatism in the United States|American conservatives]] in the [[U.S. Congress]].<ref name="fey-1978"/> As one of the participants in creating SSMCIS, James T. Fey of Teachers College, later wrote, "Schools and societal expectations of schools appear to change very slowly."<ref name="fey-1978"/> In the end, SSMCIS never became widely adopted.<ref name="walmsley"/>
==Legacy== One SSMCIS student, [[Toomas Hendrik Ilves]] of [[Leonia High School]], decades later became [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Estonia)|Foreign Minister]] and then [[President of Estonia]].<ref name="nj2016"/> He credited the SSMCIS course, the early exposure it gave him to computer programming, and the teacher of the course, Christine Cummings, with his subsequent interest in computer infrastructure, which in part resulted in the country leaping over its [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-era technological backwardness; computer-accessible education became pervasive in [[Education in Estonia|Estonian schools]], and the [[Internet in Estonia]] has one of the highest penetration rates in the world.<ref name="record">{{cite news | url=http://www.president.ee/en/media/interviews/3304-qfrom-estonia-to-leoniaq-the-record-23-april-2008/ | title=From Estonia to Leonia | first=Herb | last=Jackson | newspaper=[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Bergen Record]] | location = | date=April 23, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.riponsociety.org/forum131thi.htm | title=The Estonian Example: Q&A with Toomas Hendrik Ilves | work=[[The Ripon Forum]] | publisher=[[Ripon Society]] | date=Winter 2013}}</ref> As his tenure as president came to a close in 2016, Ilves visited his old school building with Cummings and said, "I owe everything to her. Because of what she taught us, my country now uses it."<ref name="nj2016">{{cite news | url=http://www.nj.com/bergen/index.ssf/2016/09/president_of_estonia_visits_his_old_nj_high_school_before_un_talk.html | title=President of Estonia visits his old N.J. high school before UN talk | first=Sara | last=Jerde | publisher=[[NJ.com]] | date=September 21, 2016}}</ref> Cummings said that SSMCIS not only introduced beginning computer programming but also taught students "how to think".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/estonian-president-a-leonia-h-s-grad-stops-by-middle-school-1.1663775 | title=Estonian president, a Leonia H.S. grad, stops by middle school | first=Andrew | last=Wyrich | newspaper=[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Bergen Record]] | date=September 21, 2016}}</ref>
SSMCIS did represent a productive exercise in thinking about mathematics curriculum, and the mathematics education literature would cite it in subsequent years, including references to it as a distinct,<ref>{{cite journal | title=Review: Geometry in the Mathematics Curriculum, Thirty-sixth Yearbook | first=James D. | last=Bristol |journal=The Mathematics Teacher | volume= 67 | issue= 5 |date=May 1974 | page= 442}}</ref> and the most radical,<ref>{{cite journal | title=What Do Mathematics Teachers Think About the High School Geometry Controversy | first=George | last=Gearhart | journal=The Mathematics Teacher | volume= 68 | issue= 6 |date=October 1975 | pages= 486–493}}</ref> approach to teaching geometry; as using functions as a unifying element of teaching mathematics;<ref>{{cite journal | title=Intuitions on Functions | first=Tommy |last=Dreyfus | first2=Theodore |last2=Eisenberg | journal=The Journal of Experimental Education | volume= 52 | issue= 2 | date=Winter 1984 | pages= 77-85}}</ref> and as its course materials having value when used as the vehicle for further research in mathematics education.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Communication of Mathematical Structure and Its Relationship to Achievement | first=Nicholas A. |last=Branca|journal=[[Journal for Research in Mathematics Education]] | volume=11 | issue= 1 |date=January 1980 | pages= 37–49 | doi=10.2307/748731}}</ref><!-- Two mentions in here, maybe some legacy stuff, maybe not: books.google.com/books?id=8FTKCaDjhZ0C&pg=PA512 -->
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Mathematics education]] [[Category:Mathematics education reform]] [[Category:Mathematics education in the United States]] [[Category:Computer science education]]
